On Thu, 9 Sep 2004 13:59:40 -0700, Craig Dickson <cdickson04@...> wrote:
> But in my experience the biggest
> problem in testing a web application is the variety of browsers and OSs
> that are out there and attempting to cover even a small set of these in
> QA is resource intensive. Small differences in rendering that need to be
> tweaked with custom CSS, or certain tags that a browser docent support,
> or keywords that mean something in one browser and not another.

The biggest problem will be judging appearance as needed for custom
CSS. No automated tool (at least not one yet written) can tell you
whether your page appearance is fine in all browsers. Some tools
(including HtmlUnit) can give simulate different JavaScript behavior
for some browsers, which can help.

Here, there is really little substitution for manually checking a
range of browsers unless you impose standards in terms of what tags
and scripting constructs are permitted. It is generally best to pick a
public standard and stick to it, eschewing proprietary extensions.
